newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybeans end down on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybeans end down on profit-taking.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended down slightly on Thursday on continued profit-taking, but speculative buying at lower levels helped push prices off their lows, traders said.
The most actively traded September 1997 contract ended at 3,382 yuan ($408) per tonne, losing three yuan. It opened at 3,350 yuan, hitting an intraday low of 3,346 and a high of 3,383.
May fell three yuan to 3,424, July fell two to 3,382, November fell 35 to 3,375 and the January, 1998, contract fell five to 3,365.
Combined volume rose to 19,000 tonnes from 9,300.

"Profit-taking at higher levels is still setting the tone for the market, but buying emerged at lower levels today, indicating the downward potential will be limited in the short term," said one trader.
He added that retail investors dominated trading on Thursday.
Analysts said they expect soybeans to move in a narrow range below the 3,400-yuan level over the next few days.
